<plug>
I would suggest to take a look at MockEjb framework that I just released (www.mockejb.org). It provides pretty decent support for running EJBs outside of the container. Except for Entity beans ( which is a subject for a different thread ), you can do pretty much anything you do in the container without going though the hassle of running the build, deploying, restarting the server, etc. Essentially it is a very lightweight EJB container implementation tailored specifically for unit testing. 
</plug>

Deploying test classes into the container ( approach supported by Cactus and JUnitEE ) has its share of problems. It takes some time to setup, deployment is still slow for most industry-leading servers, the app should be re-deployed even after a simple test class change. So in my view it is not very suitable for test-driven development. 

Alexander.

  It's a good first step, but after running large test suites on the app server for a while you'll want something faster. For anyone who's never done it before, they should try the approach described in the article and discover the flaws as they come up. In the meantime, we're describing those flaws and how to deal with them as quickly as we can.
